Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Geological Activity Associated with Off-Axis Melt Sills near the East Pacific Rise
Award.AbstractNarration: Two Alvin dives on the flank of the East Pacific Rise near 9Â°50'N will investigate the seafloor overlying the two largest crustal magma lenses detected by 3D multichannel seismic studies. At a distance of 5-7 km from the spreading axis, the results will document any recent faulting, flow, hydrothermal and associated biological activity across each hill. Changes as plate age increases, or along the faults bounding each hill will also be determined at each site. This information will be used to evaluate the role of off-axis magma in powering volcanic and hydrothermal activity. Post-cruise analysis will reconstruct the tectonic and volcanic history of the site using visual estimates of relative lava age and geologic contacts, radiometric dating of lava and sediment analysis for microbial activity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The discovery of shallow, crust-level magma lenses on the ridge flanks at fast and intermediate spreading-rate ridges is one of the most unexpected and interesting results in the last decade of research on seafloor spreading. These discoveries raise many questions, such as: does this magma erupt off-axis?  And, does it drive hydrothermal circulation on the ridge flanks? What is the effect on the subseafloor biosphere? In November 2014, two Alvin submersible dives were made to locations directly overlying seismically detected off-axis melt lenses to seek answers to these questions and others.

In these dives, Alvin 4771 and 4774, we successfully traversed over the seafloor above melt lenses, collected rock samples for laboratory analysis to determine eruption ages, sediment cores to measure sediment thickness and microbial activity, and several hours of video images to review for geological mapping of relative ages and contacts between lava flows. Prior to these dives, CTD tow-yo casts were run over areas with a high likelihood of hosting hydrothermal vents. However, no signals of hydrothermal plumes were found with either the nephelometer for detecting particle plumes, nor the oxidation-reduction sensor, or detecting metals in the water. While no single Alvin dive can cover enough terrain to completely eliminate the possibility, we were able to cover a representative area that leaves little doubt about the nature of the seafloor overlying off-axis melt lenses such as these. So what do we know? First, we know now that there are neither extensive nor ubiquitous areas of present volcanism or hydrothermal venting overlying the off-axis melt lenses. This is news because no one has looked previously in the specific locations of the magma bodies. Second, we know that the small volcanic cones clearly overprint the seafloor fabric built at the ridge axis and are fairly young (100-1000 yrs) judging from sediment thickness and glass weathering on the lava. Therefore, off-axis melt lenses are likely to drive more short-term or episodic volcanism along with associated hydrothermal venting and biological communities. Third, since we know that low-T hydrothermal systems develop on the ridge flanks and abyssal hills of the EPR, these features are likely to be more permeability (fracture) controlled than heat-limited.
